aria-label="Previous"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-left"></use></svg> </button> <button class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-next" type="button" aria-label="Next"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-right"></use></svg> </button> </div> </div></div> </bsp-carousel> </div> </div><p>In 2016, when public universities went months without state funding during a historic budget impasse, Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicagotribune.com/2016/01/22/rev-jackson-speaks-in-support-of-cash-strapped-chicago-state/" target="_blank" ><u>called attention</u></a> to the dire situation at Chicago State University, the state‚Äôs only predominantly Black university. Chicago State relies heavily on state aid, and the funding delay <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2016/4/29/18395666/300-layoffs-at-chicago-state-university" target="_blank" ><u>pushed the university to lay off hundreds of staff</u></a> and end the school year early.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://abc7chicago.com/post/rev-jesse-jackson-joins-chicago-state-students-in-funding-rally/1226255/" target="_blank" ><u>Jackson protested alongside Chicago State students</u></a> and gave the keynote speech at the university‚Äôs commencement that year ‚Äî support that <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/_CharlesPreston/status/2023932520027369595" target="_blank" ><u>students remembered a decade later</u></a>.</p><p>In 2021, at the age of 80 and still wearing a bandage from a recent fall, Jackson rallied alongside Black law students from the University of Illinois Chicago who alleged that a professor called them racial slurs. The professor denied those claims, but students said Jackson‚Äôs presence helped to elevate their voices.</p><p>"He‚Äôs made so many changes so that we can have these liberties to actually be able to go to law school,‚Äù UIC law student Erica Fatima <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2021/11/4/22764049/jesse-jackson-black-uic-law-students-protest-professor-kilborn-howard-university-hospital-fall" target="_blank" ><u>told the Sun-Times at the time</u></a>. ‚ÄúTo have him come and stand with us, it‚Äôs just incredible. It really is everything."</p>
entries.author: Kalyn Belsha

entries.title: Teachers could qualify for new tax breaks in 2026
entries.summary: <p>Teachers who spend their own money on classroom supplies and other learning materials could earn a larger tax break, starting this year.</p><p>But they‚Äôll also face a heavier burden to track and report those expenses, which could affect the resources teachers bring into their classroom, particularly in underserved areas, experts warned.</p><p>Changes to the educator expense deduction were made under President Donald Trump‚Äôs wide-ranging tax and spending bill, known as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act. The Joint Committee on Taxation estimates that the expanded deduction would reduce tax collections by $200 million through 2034.</p><p>The bill also permanently removes the ability for filers, like teachers, to deduct so-called ‚Äúmiscellaneous expenses.‚Äù</p><p>For the 2025 tax year, eligible educators ‚Äî teachers, counselors, classroom aides, principals and other K-12 instructors at a state-recognized school ‚Äî with at least 900 hours of annual employment are allowed to claim up to $300 "above-the-line," or $600 for joint filers, if each spouse qualifies. An above-the-line deduction reduces your adjusted gross income.</p><p>Qualified expenses include:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-eec1ec32-fae0-11f0-a41a-b925e60fa400"><li>Books and other learning materials, except athletic supplies for health and physical education classes</li><li>Classroom supplies such as paper and art supplies</li><li>Computers, software and related accessories</li><li>Instructional equipment and supplementary materials</li><li>Professional development courses tied directly to teaching</li></ul><p>Illinois teachers can also benefit from the state's K-12 Instructional Materials and Supplies credit that provides a $500 tax credit per educator, according to Elizabeth Buffardi, founder of Crescendo Financial Planners in Oak Brook.</p><p>Eligible expenses are similar to those under the federal educator expense deduction, such as school supplies and equipment. The state credit is available to K-12 teachers, instructors, counselors, principals or aides in a qualified school, working at least 900 hours during the school year, according to the Illinois Department of Revenue. The maximum credit is $1,000 for married couples filing jointly, who are both eligible educators.</p><p>‚ÄúWhile these credits are helpful, most teachers spend more than this for their classrooms,‚Äù Buffardi said.</p><h3>Changes for 2026</h3><p>For the 2026 tax year, the bill's definition of eligible educator will include coaches and interscholastic sports administrators. It also broadens eligible items from "in the classroom" to "as part of instructional activity," according to the legislation.</p><p>And an educator's deduction increases from $300 to $350, or $700 for married couples, if both are eligible educators, according to Buffardi.</p><p>However, itemized deductions will be allowed for qualifying classroom expenses without a dollar limit. Taxpayers should be aware of a key caveat under the new rule.</p><p>‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt itemize, you get no [extra] deduction at all,‚Äù Mark Gallegos, tax partner at Porte Brown, said.</p><p>So a teacher who spent $1,400 in qualifying expenses this year could take the $350 deduction, which lowers their adjusted gross income, and because they itemized, they can deduct the remaining $1,050 on their Schedule A. Previously, only $300 would have been deductible.</p><p>‚ÄúIf you haven't been able to itemize for the past several years, you‚Äôll want to look to see if you‚Äôll be able to itemize in 2026,‚Äù Buffardi said. ‚ÄúWith the changes to the itemizing rules, more people may be able to itemize than in the past several years.‚Äù</p><p>The policy shift should prompt teachers to reassess their tax planning strategies, Florida attorney David Weisselberger said.</p><p>‚ÄúMany educators will be forced to weigh the benefits of the simplicity of the cap on the new deduction against the added complexity of restoring itemized deductions and will likely face significant challenges in doing so, ultimately placing an indirect strain on the resources available for their classrooms as a direct result of their increased financial burdens,‚Äù he said.</p><h3>Changes favor higher-income filers</h3><p>Teachers who itemize may benefit more because they can deduct everything they spend, but the advantages could skew toward high-income filers, according to Gallegos. Taxpayers who itemize tend to be higher-income or homeowners.</p><p>‚ÄúIn practice, lower and many middle-income teachers are less likely to itemize, particularly if they‚Äôre renters or have modest mortgage/property tax expenses,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat means the benefit is tilted toward teachers with higher income or larger itemized deductions.‚Äù</p><p>Weisselberger said the legislation removed a long-held tax benefit for unreimbursed teachers ‚Äî miscellaneous expenses.</p><p>‚ÄúLower-income educators may find that the reduction of miscellaneous expense deductions results in a disproportionate increase in their annual tax liability because they typically rely on credits, rather than itemizing deductions and/or utilizing the standard deduction,‚Äù he stated in an email.</p><p>Nearly every teacher spends their own money on classroom supplies, regardless of the school's location and resources, said Bridget Eaglin, a longtime early childhood educator at public and private schools in Chicago and the northwest suburbs.</p><p>Many common items teachers buy, like sticky notes and project materials, are often unreimbursed since most spend more than the $300 cap, and many teachers don't itemize their expenses, a rather laborious task.</p><p>Eaglin, who taught preschool last year at St. Paul of the Cross in Park Ridge, estimated as many as half of teachers ultimately front the bill. In Illinois, the average teacher spent about $890 out of pocket on schools supplies during the 2024-2025 school year, according to a survey by crowdfunding site AdoptAClassroom. Nationally, the figure was $895.</p><p>The resource gap between school districts is a perennial concern for students, teachers and parents, educators told the Chicago Sun-Times.</p><p>In better-resourced school districts, most supplies are provided by the school, parent-teacher organizations and community fundraising efforts.</p><p>‚ÄúIn under-resourced or inner-city schools, teachers often dig deeper into their own pockets to fill the gaps,‚Äù Gallegos said. ‚ÄúWhen the tax system removes or sharply limits deductions for those costs, it increases the real net cost to those teachers."</p>
entries.author: Chris Casacchia

entries.title: How to avoid an underpayment penalty by the IRS
entries.summary: <p>There are a few strategies taxpayers can take to make sure they pay enough taxes throughout the year to avoid an underpayment penalty.</p><p>An underpayment penalty is a charge the IRS imposes on taxpayers who didn't pay all of their estimated income taxes for the year or who paid their taxes late. </p><p> An underpayment penalty will apply if:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-8d2d5d50-fcc6-11f0-9ff9-017322a4fb4d"><li>A person didn‚Äôt pay at least 90% of the tax on their current-year return or 100% of the tax shown on the prior year‚Äôs return.</li><li>A person paid their estimated taxes late.</li></ul><p>If a person works for an employer, they may be hit with this penalty because the tax that was withheld from their paycheck during the year didn‚Äôt cover their full tax liability. An independent contractor may be penalized for missing or underpaying one of the quarterly estimated tax payments.</p><p>This penalty only applies to those who owe $1,000 or more in unpaid taxes. If a person is subject to this charge, they'll receive an IRS notice in the mail.</p><p>Note that there are special rules for taxpayers whose adjusted gross income for the previous year was more than $150,000, or $75,000 if married and filing separately. Rather than 100%, you must have paid 110% of the tax on your prior year‚Äôs return to avoid the underpayment penalty.</p><h3>Underpayment penalty rate</h3><p>The underpayment penalty is calculated by multiplying how much tax a person owed for each quarter by the interest rate for that quarter.</p><p>For the quarter through March, the underpayment penalty interest rate is 7%, which remains the same as it has been throughout 2025.</p><h3>Avoiding the penalty</h3><p>If a person paid at least 90% of the tax on their current-year return or 100% of the tax shown on the prior year‚Äôs return, they can avoid the underpayment penalty for estimated taxes.</p><p>Another way for a person to avoid an underpayment penalty in the future is to adjust withholdings on their W-4 if they have an employer. Reducing the number of dependents or adding an extra withholding amount on line 4(c) can help ensure a person is having enough tax withheld from their paycheck to cover their tax bill. One can use the IRS tax withholding estimator on its <a class="Link" href="https://www.irs.gov/individuals/tax-withholding-estimator" target="_blank" >website</a> to check whether they're on track.</p><p>An independent contractor who pays quarterly estimated taxes needs to stay on top of each quarter's due date and make sure they're accurately calculating and paying what they owe.</p><h3>Exceptions to the underpayment penalty</h3><p>The IRS may waive an underpayment penalty under certain circumstances, such as when:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-8d2d5d52-fcc6-11f0-9ff9-017322a4fb4d"><li>A person had the majority of their income tax withheld at the beginning of the year.</li><li>A person has varying income throughout the year.</li><li>A person became disabled and had reasonable cause to underpay.</li><li>A person retired in the last two years after reaching age 62 and had reasonable cause to underpay.</li><li>A person went through an unforeseen circumstance, like a disaster or a casualty.</li><li>A person is a farmer or fisherman who paid all tax due by March 1.</li></ul><h3>If a person can‚Äôt pay their bill on time</h3><p>A tax return should be filed by the April 15 deadline, even if a person can‚Äôt afford to pay their bill. The IRS imposes a failure-to-file penalty on taxpayers who file late or don‚Äôt file, a fee that's typically 5% of any unpaid taxes for each month or partial month, up to a maximum of 25%.</p><p>It‚Äôs also a good idea for a person to pay as much as they can when they file. On top of the underpayment interest charge, one could face a late payment penalty ‚Äî sometimes called the failure-to-pay penalty. This is an additional charge of 0.5% of any unpaid taxes for each month or partial month the tax goes unpaid, capped at 25% of a person's tax bill.</p><p>If this all sounds a bit overwhelming, there is some good news. The IRS offers payment plans that allow taxpayers to pay their bill over time. </p><p>Getting on a payment plan can help reduce penalties. For instance, the late-payment penalty is cut in half. It can also prevent a tax levy or lien.</p>
entries.author: Bella Avila | NerdWallet

entries.title: How changes to the child tax credit and other policies will impact parents
entries.summary: <p>Parents looking for tax breaks in the 2025 tax year will find many options available to them, while undocumented and mixed-status families are at risk of losing certain federal tax benefits.</p><p>As President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration seeks to curb immigration, it‚Äôs also going after benefits that have historically been available to immigrant families.</p><p>Last year‚Äôs passage of the "One Big Beautiful Bill," included tax provisions that permanently increased the federal child tax credit from $2,000 to $2,200 per child under age 17, with annual adjustments for inflation starting in 2026. The credit phases out for single filers with a modified adjusted gross income of $200,000, or $400,000 for those married filing jointly.</p><p>But undocumented individuals or mixed status families may no longer be able to claim the credit, due to changes in the filing requirements.</p><p>That‚Äôs because the law now requires a parent, or spouse if filing jointly, to have a Social Security number, as well as the qualifying child. The change could impact around 176,000 children, who are U.S. citizens with undocumented parents, according to data from the Migration Policy Institute.</p><p>Before the bill passed last year, taxpayers could file with a taxpayer identification number, or TIN, which is commonly used among the immigrant community and for those without a Social Security number.</p><p>If a parent has little to no income tax liability, they could qualify for the additional child tax credit that provides up to $1,700 per qualifying child. The additional child tax credit allows low-income families to receive a cash payment, compared to the child tax credit that reduces a family‚Äôs tax liability.</p><p>In order to receive the additional credit, taxpayers are required to have earned income of at least $2,500.</p><p>This could impact veteran families, particularly those who are transitioning into the civilian workforce and may not yet have an income, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. The center estimates 21,000 veteran families in Illinois could be affected by the income threshold.</p><p>Veteran and immigrant families with at least one child under 12 may still be eligible for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/taxes/illinois-eitc-earned-income-tax-credit-claimed" >Illinois child tax credit</a>, which is 40% of a taxpayer‚Äôs state earned income tax credit, for tax year 2025. The benefit would be $300 to $600 per family, double the amount available last year.</p><h3>Dependent care credits</h3><p>There‚Äôs also a federal credit for other dependents, available to families with dependents who don‚Äôt meet the criteria to claim the child tax credit or additional child tax credit.</p><p>Filers can claim the $500 credit for a dependent child over age 16 or another dependent relative. The credit was available under the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and was made permanent with the passage of the new tax and spending bill, with the same income-based phaseouts as the child tax credit.</p><p>Another valuable tax credit for families is the child and dependent care credit, which covers a percentage of child care expenses for children under 13 or dependents who can‚Äôt care for themselves.</p><p>Trump‚Äôs so-called One Big Beautiful Bill Act allows taxpayers to claim up to 50% of eligible expenses, starting this year. But the amount of expenses used to calculate the credit remains the same at $3,000 for one person, or $6,000 for two or more people, according to H&R Block.</p><p>The credit also phases down at higher income levels compared to previous years.</p><p>The 2025 federal tax bill expanded the annual contribution limit on dependent care accounts as well. Administered through certain employers, dependent care accounts ‚Äî also known as flexible spending accounts ‚Äî can now receive pretax contributions of up to $7,500 (up from $5,000) to be used for work-related child care expenses, including summer day camp.</p><h3>Adoption tax credit</h3><p>Adopting a child can be expensive, but some parents will see a significant tax relief to help offset some of the costs. Parents can claim the credit if the child is under age 18, or physically or mentally incapable of self-care.</p><p>For 2025, the maximum credit for qualified adoption expenses increases to $17,820 per child, up from $16,810 in 2024.</p><p>But one significant change started in 2025: Taxpayers who adopt can receive a refundable credit of up to $5,000. Prior to the bill‚Äôs passing, the federal credit was nonrefundable, so it could reduce the taxes owed to zero, but it couldn‚Äôt provide a tax refund.</p><p>Income limits were also adjusted under the massive bill. For the 2025 tax year, the full credit is available to filers with a modified adjusted gross income of up to $259,190. The credit phases out and becomes unavailable to those whose MAGI equals or exceeds $299,190.</p><h3>Child savings accounts</h3><p>Also new this year: Trump Accounts.</p><p>For American citizens who have a baby between Jan. 1, 2025, and Dec. 31, 2028, the federal government will contribute $1,000 into a 530A account, also known as a Trump Account, on the child‚Äôs behalf. The account is similar to an individual retirement account and is expected to be available starting July.</p><p>Families can make annual after-tax contributions of up to $5,000. Employers and charitable organizations may also make contributions into the child‚Äôs account.</p><p>From ages 18 to 30, the child can withdraw the funds tax-free as long as it‚Äôs used for qualifying expenses such as higher education, job training, a first-time home purchase, starting a small business or certain workforce expenses. After age 30, the money is taxed as ordinary income.</p><p>Parents can fill out the new Form 4547 or elect to wait for an online portal that is expected to open in mid-2026.</p><p>Amanda Paton, partner and owner of Deerfield-based Clover CPAs and Consultants, said Trump Accounts are ‚Äúnot this overwhelming advantage, but it is something.‚Äù</p><p>She said the help is more limited given that Trump‚Äôs bill also cut funding for Medicaid and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.</p><p>Meanwhile, the bill expanded how 529 plans can be used. The tax-advantaged accounts are an option for families who want to save for their child‚Äôs educational expenses.</p><p>The bill expanded qualifying expenses for K-12 costs to include tutoring, standardized test fees, books and more. And as of Jan. 1, parents can withdraw $20,000 per year to pay for K-12 expenses, up from $10,000.</p>
entries.author: Lizzie Kane

entries.title: Small businesses survive with support from their communities, Chicago's Next Voices columnist writes
entries.summary: <p>When I was a graduate student at Columbia College Chicago, studying entrepreneurship for creatives, our biggest assignment was to make a pitch for a new business.</p><p>My idea was a small company that specialized in digital media services, combining my love of writing, production and other forms of content creation.</p><p>I graduated in 2022, and I still plan to start that business one day. It‚Äôs a dream to be one of the thousands of small businesses that fuel the city‚Äôs economy, but I realized I needed to do my part and support local businesses now.</p><p>Growing up in Chicago, I always had plenty of places to shop and services to choose from, but I never really thought about whether a business was family owned or independent.</p><p>It became a habit to shop at national chains because they were the cheapest options. This includes using repair services at well-known companies rather than searching for an independent service provider. Recently, I realized I was becoming a part of a bigger problem. One that is hurting local businesses.</p><p>In 2024, UIC Business, in partnership with the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce, <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicagolandchamber.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/2024-Small-Business-Outlook-Survey.pdf" target="_blank" >conducted a study</a> of small businesses in the Chicago metropolitan area. More than 200 companies across various industries completed a survey that asked about their concerns, outlook and performance.</p><p>The results in the "expectation of business performance" section showed that many expected their businesses to perform about the same in the next 12 months. However, UIC Business' 2025 survey <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicagolandchamber.org/statements-releases/chicagoland-chamber-of-commerce-unveils-2025-small-business-survey-findings-in-partnership-with-uic-business/" target="_blank" >shows a decline</a> in performance confidence, dropping from 71% to 49%.</p><p>One hundred and forty-eight businesses participated in the 2025 survey, many of which were service-based. Fifty-seven percent said they would improve existing products or services as their specific growth strategy, with increased marketing and promotion, and adding new products or services.</p><p>Mandy Carpenter, a Chicago event planner/stylist who founded ARK Event Styling in 2015, changed her pricing and expanded her services to help her business grow after a drop in clients during the pandemic.</p><p>‚ÄúThe biggest challenge my business faced was a sharp decline in clients as event planning and styling became financially out of reach for many families and organizations. While the desire to gather and celebrate remained, budgets were tighter, and priorities had shifted,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúARK responded by adjusting pricing, creating flexible service options and even bartering services to support clients who still wanted meaningful moments. That shift allowed us to stay in business while staying connected to the community we serve.‚Äù</p><p>Small business owners are finding ways to grow and adjust, and I‚Äôll do my part as a Chicagoan and use my favorite phrase, "Put your money where your mouth is." </p><p>I‚Äôve made a 12-month plan to buy from a different local business or try a new service. I started with a pair of earrings from Lindsay Lewis Jewelry in Humboldt Park, and each month will have a theme. For example, in February I‚Äôll look for a Black-owned business, in March a woman-owned one, and in April, something eco-friendly for Earth Day.</p><p>I plan to use local Chamber of Commerce websites and social media to find more businesses. Then, I‚Äôll recommend my favorites to friends and family and share my experiences online to help spread the word.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div entries.title: Are the Bears using Hammond and other places as a bluff to get a better deal in Chicago?
entries.summary: <p>The day after he proposed a special tax on social-media companies, cutting red tape on Illinois zoning laws and a push toward serious affordability against all and everything coming out of the White House in his $56 billion budget in his State of the State address, Gov. JB Pritzker prepared to enter back into the Illinois state capitol only to find out that the conversation he was about to hear concerning the Bears and their ‚Äúnext‚Äù stadium soap opera had been canceled.</p><p>‚ÄúScrapped‚Äù is how one newspaper put it. ‚ÄúPostponed‚Äù is how some people apparently were referring to it on the legislative floor. ‚ÄúPause to the hearing‚Äù was the term used in the statement from the Bears. ‚ÄúDisappointed‚Äù was Pritzker‚Äôs word choice after hearing the Bears‚Äô statement. ‚ÄúWhatever‚Äù seems to be the word being tossed around by everyone else not directly connected to the process of deciding where the Bears‚Äô home games are going to take place in 2033.</p><p>So what are they really doing here? What is really going on?</p><p>There‚Äôs understanding that negotiating eight years out from the end of a residency deal is necessary, but bidding on ‚Äî excuse me, bargaining between ‚Äî two places outside of Chicago that have nothing to offer outside of land and opportunity (no historical or cultural connection at all) seems less like a strategy and more like a game is being played with hope that miraculously the lakefront-stadium concept will resurface at the 11:30 p.m. half-hour to keep the Chicago skyline orange and blue.</p><p>The Bears‚Äô no-show Thursday on the slowly becoming infamous House Bill 2789 leaves open doors of thought and conspiracy that have the power to backfire in the Bears‚Äô face if they don‚Äôt play this game perfectly or things don‚Äôt magically work out in this political/business/real estate situation the way things magically did on the field for them all season. Even with their appearance in front of the Illinois House committee being rescheduled for Thursday.</p><p>Three-card monte is what they seem to be playing. But this ain‚Äôt being played in the back of a CTA bus. These are three municipalities being tossed over and around and beside one another by one of the legacy franchises in sports history, pitting each one against the other to help themselves make a decision. A 55-year, over $2 billion-$4 billion decision.</p><p>An arduous mission. In the hands and under the watch of Bears president/CEO Kevin Warren, this is leaning toward making him the fall guy and the one to blame if ‚Äî when ‚Äî the Bears no longer reside in Chicago because of a tax-certainty technicality. (And the fact that Chicago has the highest sales-tax rate in the nation at 10.5%, and our tax rate on commercial properties is double the national average vs. Indiana‚Äôs set state sales tax of 7%, and a considerably lower tax rate on commercial property doesn‚Äôt help.)</p><p>The stress, panic and desperation of the ‚ÄúHammond Bears‚Äù all enter the 36 Chambers even as the Bears continue to hold lawmakers hostage in Springfield. Is this just a ploy? A bluff? Are the Bears just using this process to better leverage the situation for them to possibly stay in Chicago? Can‚Äôt you see Hammond Mayor Thomas McDermott Jr. and Arlington Heights Village President Jim Tinaglia huddling up, trying not to argue, as they realize the game the Bears are playing could be on both of them?</p><p>Indiana House members of the Ways and Means Committee voted 24-0 to issue bonds to finance, lease and build a stadium that would put the Bears‚Äô name on it. And attached to that unanimous sense of thirst comes a desperate-feeling sense of urgency because the clock is ticking. At least for this year. Indiana‚Äôs lawmakers will be in session only until Friday. For Illinois legislators, their general assembly will be in session until the end of May. Again, the Bears won‚Äôt technically become homeless until 2033.</p><p>Then there‚Äôs the ‚Äúfiscal responsibility‚Äù somehow lost in the ‚Äúmegaprojects‚Äù deal. The $84 million thrown away by vacating the lease with the Park District early, the almost $200 million ($197.2 million, to keep it exact) they let go to acquire the land in Arlington Heights if they go elsewhere, the remaining $356 million bill on the spaceship renovations done to Soldier Field in 2003. (An amount that has now been debted to us Chicago taxpayers with an added max interest that could hit us up for up to $534 million.)</p><p>Math it all up. It‚Äôs only hundreds of millions in a multibillion-dollar legislation.</p><p>Soon there more than likely will be a third Chicago mayor attached to this. Soon there might be a Super Bowl-contending team attached to this. Not so soon will a decision be made on where exactly the new Bears playpen will be. Because the Bears are playing all sides against one another.</p><p>Is this all speculation? Damn right it is. But it‚Äôs speculation based on moves that have made ‚Äúbig bank take little bank‚Äù a high-end corporate American business normality. The Bears as a franchise are probably worth more than both of the outside cities vying to build a stadium for them to play in. And they haven‚Äôt totally given up on leaving this city they call home. So ask yourself: Who‚Äôs the mack?<br></p>
entries.author: Scoop Jackson

entries.title: Hall of Famer Steve McMichael's widow Misty arrested
entries.summary: <p>Misty McMichael, who successfully lobbied for her husband Steve‚Äôs inclusion into the Pro Football Hall of Fame before his death in April, was arrested Friday and charged with domestic battery.</p><p>Will County sheriffs arrested the 55-year-old at a Frankfort home, where she was accused by an unnamed man of arguing for hours and choking him. A witness said the two had been arguing. Records indicate she was charged with misdemeanor domestic battery and physical contact. She was booked at 7:23 a.m. Friday.</p><p>Steve ‚ÄúMongo‚Äù McMichael <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2025/04/23/bears-steve-mcmichael-dies-obituary-als-hall-of-fame-defensive-lineman-nfl" target="_blank" >died at 67 in April</a>, four years after being diagnosed with ALS. The defensive lineman played for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> from 1981 to 1993 and ranks second in franchise history in sacks and third in tackles. </p><p>He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in August 2024 after a successful lobbying effort. He received a gold jacket at his Homer Glen, with fellow Hall of Famers Richard Dent, Jimbo Covert and Mike Singletary by his bedside.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Dear Abby: Widow discovers late husband's life was full of secrets
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My late husband was ill for six years. He experienced some dementia. He wasn't able to work, and our life together changed a lot. I focused on supporting him through his decline until he eventually ended his own life.</p><p>After his death, I discovered several secrets. He hadn't been honest about his medical condition, possibly out of shame or because he wanted to protect us from the seriousness. There were also secrets about his family he may have been ashamed about. He also changed his estate plan without telling me. These secrets and betrayals show he wasn't thinking about the impact of his death upon me, and they have made me question my beliefs about our marriage.</p><p>I know his decisions weren't about my worth ‚Äî they were about his fear, shame, illness and preoccupation with other family issues. But I can't tell any of this to people because I want to preserve our adult children's love and respect for their father. Also, I don't want to deal with other people trying to understand this crazy situation. This feels so unfair, and I may never be able to trust again. Do you have any advice? ‚Äî <i>KEEPING SECRETS IN NEW ENGLAND</i></p><p><b>DEAR KEEPING:</b> Please accept my sympathy for the loss of your husband. From what you have written, it seems the problems in your marriage started with the family secrets in addition to your husband's increasing dementia. My advice is to put an end to all of those secrets now. Telling your children the truth should not make them lose respect for their late father. Whether the people in whom you choose to confide will understand is beside the point.</p><p>What's most important is that you free yourself from the prison of lies in which you find yourself and talk with a mental health professional if it will help you better understand how to move forward.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My family is American, through and through. We had some European ancestors back in the Ellis Island days, but we've been here for generations and identify only loosely with our European heritage. That being said, my husband and I were discussing names for our future children, and I mentioned that I would love to have a son named after my great-grandfather. His name was Jacques, but it was always pronounced like "Jack."</p><p>If I used the name, I would want to spell it the same way to honor him, but I'd feel weird pronouncing it with a French accent when I don't identify as French, nor do I have an accent. Is it OK to use the French spelling of a name and then pronounce it in an Americanized way? ‚Äî <i>PLANNING AHEAD IN SOUTH CAROLINA</i></p><p><b>DEAR PLANNING:</b> You are the parent, and you can call your son whatever you wish. Jacques will be his formal name if you choose to use it on his birth certificate, but he can use "Jack" if he wishes. When he starts school, don't forget to communicate to his teachers and the administrators how his name is pronounced.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>For everything you need to know about wedding planning, order "How to Have a Lovely Wedding." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Wedding Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: Rev. Jackson's message of hope resonates well beyond Chicago
entries.summary: <p>To really appreciate the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/obituary/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-embodied-era-civil-rights-leadership-natalie-moore?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=02172026%20Morning%20Edition&utm_content=02172026%20Morning%20Edition+CID_18ae33b9ac0c6725278bbe9fb4d34c16&utm_source=cst_campaign_monitor&utm_term=Rev%20Jackson%20was%20a%20symbol%20of%20Black%20politics%20and%20Black%20America&tpcc=cst_cm" target="_blank" >Rev. Jesse Jackson</a> Sr. I think you have to step outside the Chicago lens, where media familiarity does not always result in the full measure of the man.</p><p>I first met him when our anti-apartheid organization hosted a visitor from the African National Congress. I ended up bringing my infant daughter with me because I was a working nursing mother. He did not bat an eye. In fact, he and the great Rev. Willie Barrow invited me to join in for the announcement of the <a class="Link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1986/12/05/business/apartheid-pullout-by-revlon.html" target="_blank" >Revlon makeup boycott</a>. This led to a lifelong collaboration and friendship. </p><p>Rev. Jackson was incredibly media literate and a skilled speaker. He hosted numerous radio and television iterations of "Keep Hope Alive," his public affairs program. Over the years, he found brilliant representatives from academia, politics and culture. He could break down complex issues and concepts, such as <a class="Link" href="https://www.tulsalibrary.org/black-wall-street" target="_blank" >Black Wall Street</a>, the 2008 housing bubble and Black farming. He could smack-talk. He could pray. </p><p>When I served as an occasional fill-in host on his national radio show or traveled to Detroit to work on his daughter Santita‚Äòs TV program, I learned that members of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition were effective, committed and everywhere.  </p><p>As a producer for "Chicago Tonight," I watched a group of Humboldt Park protesters gain strength as they shouted, "Jesse is here,‚Äù when he appeared at their Puerto Rican protest, and cameras came too. Jesse was able to uplift voices and issues to serve others. </p><p>Watching him celebrate his daughter surrounded by children and grandchildren, he was quiet, loving and, yes, humble. </p><p>In a world that is quick to cannibalize Black culture and diminish our history, what can we do in this moment? Let‚Äôs show compassion and care, not only to his family but also to the contemporaries he leaves behind who are suffering on a personal level. Let‚Äôs get the story right and pass it on to our children with all the lessons and complexity that his life has to offer. Let‚Äôs "Keep Hope Alive," with an added dose of resilience!</p><p><i>Sylvia Ewing, vice president</i> <i>of</i> <i>journalism and media engagement, Public Narrative</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-2c0000" name="module-2c0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Give us your take</h3><br>Send letters to the editor to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. To be considered for publication, letters must include your full name, your neighborhood or hometown and a phone number for verification purposes. Letters should be a maximum of approximately 375 words.</div> </div><p></p><h3>Sun-Times captured Jackson‚Äôs legacy </h3><p>Congratulations, Sun-Times, with much gratitude, for your extraordinary journalistic homage to the Rev. Jesse Jackson ‚Äî an American political giant who diligently built, for multiple generations, a sturdy and reliable bridge between the 1960s Civil Rights Movement and today's fight against social and racial injustice.</p><p>Your 20-page special section honoring the multiple legacies of Rev. Jackson eloquently surpassed the journalistic coverage of other outstanding newspapers such as the New York Times, USA Today and the Chicago Tribune.</p><p>Your historically robust visual archive of Rev. Jackson's political journey through the decades reminded me of when I saw him run for president in the 1980s when I was still a young Mexican immigrant college student. That moment made me realize that the names of Americans of color, both within and outside my community, could actually get prominent national recognition in the world of politics.</p><p>In my view, Rev. Jackson broke the presidential race ceiling in the late 20th century for our own 21st century President Barack Obama.</p><p>Perhaps even more importantly, Rev. Jackson's moral vision for a better society, including his ongoing belief in a "rainbow coalition" that truly captures the multicultural American society that we have always been, offers a compelling map for how to nurture a better America for the new generations.</p><p>May Rev. Jesse Jackson rest in peace and power.</p><p><i>Alejandro Lugo, Park Forest</i></p><h3>Latino heritage rooted in Chicago </h3><p>In the first week of January, I traveled to Chicago to meet with historic preservation partners ‚Äî from established practitioners to grassroots neighborhood leaders. In La Villita ‚Äî Little Village ‚Äî community leaders spoke about what it now takes to remain in place: keeping businesses open, families together and neighborhoods intact amid federal immigration enforcement pressure and ongoing uncertainty.</p><p>What is unfolding here reflects a national moment that is redefining how American history is interpreted and preserved.</p><p>As the United States nears its 250th anniversary, public attention is turning toward questions of origin, belonging and national memory. Chicago has long influenced how the country understands culture, civic life and preservation. Latino communities are part of that continuum, visible across neighborhoods, institutions and public space, even when their presence is treated as recent or temporary.</p><p>In historic neighborhoods like Little Village and Pilsen, the past is lived daily through family-owned businesses, housing stability and community networks that allow residents to remain rooted.</p><p>Actions such as Operation Midway Blitz, which separated thousands of families, continue to affect how residents move through their neighborhoods, how businesses operate and how communities organize for safety and mutual support.</p><p>That context is why, in August, Latinos in Heritage Conservation will bring its national historic preservation conference, Congreso, to Chicago.</p><p>This region is a living archive of migration, labor, resistance and reinvention. Afro Latino, Indigenous, Mexican, Central American, Caribbean and working-class communities have shaped its cultural landscape for generations. Decisions about community safety, displacement and who is able to remain are happening now, and preservation must be part of them.</p><p>It is also a place where Latino communities have carried that legacy forward through everyday stewardship, sustaining family-owned businesses, organizing for housing stability and protecting cultural spaces that anchor community life. This year, we will gather not to observe this history, but to stand within it and to affirm clearly and publicly that we are here, and we have always been here.</p><p><i>Sehila Mota Casper, executive director, Latinos in Heritage Conservation</i></p><h3>Funding parity for charter students is not a bailout</h3><p>Recent coverage of financial distress facing some <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2026/02/11/cps-charter-school-cant-make-payroll-insolvent-closed-march-aspira-chiarts-cpsboard" >charter schools</a> has focused on whether Chicago Public Schools should provide short-term financial support. The coverage mischaracterizes these payments as "bailouts," when in actuality they are the foreseeable consequence of many years of structural underfunding.</p><p>CPS is required by law to provide charter schools at least 97% of the state‚Äôs per capita tuition charge. Yet after deducting pension, debt service, management fees and other districtwide costs, charter schools receive, on average, roughly 83% of that amount. That means thousands of dollars less per student, even when charter and district-run schools serve similar student populations in the same neighborhoods.</p><p>In one example reported by <a class="Link" href="https://www.chalkbeat.org/chicago/2026/02/11/chicago-public-schools-charter-financial-problems/#:~:text=Does%20CPS%20fund%20charters%20equitably,the%20entire%20district%20is%20facing." target="_blank" >Chalkbeat Chicago</a>, two high schools with fewer than 300 students share a building on the Far South Side. Noble‚Äôs Baker College Prep, a charter public school, received $15,800 per student this year, while the district-run Bowen High School received $25,150 per student, according to CPS data. The building is the same. The students are similar. The funding is not.</p><p>CPS data also shows that 287 of 498 school buildings are categorized as underutilized. Some schools have fewer than 200 students. Douglass High School has just 28 students in a building built for 912. District-run schools receive guaranteed staffing positions regardless of enrollment and are subsidized to remain open. Charter schools, by contrast, are funded largely based on enrollment alone, even though 87% of charter students live in poverty compared with 69% in district-run schools.</p><p>Charter schools are concentrated on the South and West sides of the city, where population decline has been steepest, but the need for high-quality public schools remains urgent. These students deserve stability and equitable funding.</p><p>When district-run schools receive additional support to remain open, we call it equity and investment<b>. </b>When charter students seek parity with their district-run peers, it should be viewed through the same lens. Every public school student in Chicago deserves fair treatment under the law and a funding system that supports their success.</p><p><i>Andrew Broy, president, Illinois Network of Charter Schools</i></p><h3>School choice is misguided choice</h3><p>It‚Äôs a shame the Archdiocese of Chicago has to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2026/01/26/archdiocese-catholic-school-closing-jerome-bruno-richard-francis-borgia-stanislaus-kostka" >close more schools </a>due to lack of funding, but saving them with taxpayer funds or vouchers is not the answer.</p><p>As education historian Dianne Ravitch <a class="Link" href="https://dianeravitch.net/2023/04/12/school-choice-will-destroy-public-schools/" target="_blank" >states</a>, ‚ÄúChoice is a means to defund what should be our common good.‚Äù Redirecting funds means fewer dollars for the neediest students. Any choice model that diverts public funds to private interests destroys the social contract that is meant to strengthen public schools for the common good.</p><p>The answer isn‚Äôt to increase the <a class="Link" href="https://tax.illinois.gov/questionsandanswers/answer.28.html" target="_blank" >Illinois K-12 education expense credit</a> for private education, as some suggest. That would further enable taxpayers to opt out of public education. The results would be catastrophic: more school closings due to lack of funding, lower property values and a higher likelihood of becoming the subject of a watchdog task force.</p><p>The archdiocese is taking the necessary steps to ease its financial burden. To grow, it may want to consider a different approach to attract students to certain parochial schools: classical education.</p><p>Depending on the parish's progressiveness, the faith community might embrace a classical education model for their children. Teachers need to work hard to ensure the school maintains state accreditation, but it has worked.</p><p>For example, over time, <a class="Link" href="https://stjeromeacademy.org/" target="_blank" >St. Jerome Academy</a> in Hyattsville, Maryland, shifted from a traditional curriculum to a classical Catholic education, which <a class="Link" href="https://www.sjaclassical.org/classical-vs-progressive-education" target="_blank" >‚Äúconsists in cultivating virtuous dispositions in students.‚Äù</a> Today, the school is at total capacity with <a class="Link" href="https://streetcarsuburbs.news/st-jerome-academy-announces-major-expansion/" target="_blank" >waitlists</a>.</p><p>St. Jerome's goal was to reimagine education. It is infinitely more effective than reshuffling funds like a shell game.</p><p><i>Mary Dooms, Hoffman Estates</i></p><h3>Bon voyage, Bears </h3><p>If the Chicago Bears want to build a new home in the Chicago suburbs, that's fine with me.<br>If they want to profit more by moving to Indiana ‚Äî a location less accessible to Chicago area fans, so be it. But they won't be the Chicago Bears to me anymore, and I won't follow their exploits. Nor, I expect, will they get the Chicago media coverage they currently enjoy. Their past glories will fade into memory like any deceased relative. Hammond Hawks, anyone?</p><p><i>Charles Berg,</i> <i>Hyde Park/Kenwood</i></p><h3>Suburban sprawl</h3><p>Now that it's very possible that the Bears will leave <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/19/chicago-bears-stadium-hammond-indiana-move" target="_blank" >Illinois and become the Hammond Bears or the Indiana Bears</a>, there will be a large vacant parcel of land in the northwest suburbs. I have a radical suggestion for the new owners of the property. They can build a racetrack there and name it Arlington Park!</p><p><i>Craig Jacobson, Skokie</i></p><h3><b>Bears move: quarterback sneak</b></h3><p>I don't have a stake in this potential relocation, but I hate the secrecy behind the process.</p><p>We saw it with the New York Giants and Jets moving to the New Jersey Meadowlands Sports Complex. By the time these funding bills get passed and news releases floated, it's often a fait accompli. Negotiations typically have already taken place, between stakeholders and local elected officials and the team ownership, long before we see it in the headlines. Unfortunately, the taxpayers who fund the new stadiums are the last to know.</p><p>But everyone wants to be an NFL town, right? So they don't complain too much.</p><p>Then again, a Bears move to Indiana (or to Iowa, as also rumored) could fall through ‚Äî like the supposed Washington Commanders move to northern Virginia a couple years ago, which never materialized.</p><p><i>Adam Silbert, New York City</i></p><h3>Baseball prayers </h3><p>Watching the recent <a class="Link" href="https://www.ncronline.org/news/music-and-multicultural-witness-ronald-hicks-begins-his-new-york-ministry" target="_blank" >installation</a> of Bishop Ronald Hicks, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/religion/2025/12/18/pope-leo-appoints-ronald-hicks-archbishop-new-york-replacing-cardinal-timothy-dolan" >a Chicago area native</a>, as archbishop of New York at St. Patrick's Cathedral, I remembered his recent comment that he will remain a <a class="Link" href="https://longisland.news12.com/pope-names-fellow-chicagoan-bishop-ronald-hicks-as-new-archbishop-of-new-york" target="_blank" >Cubs fan</a>.</p><p>As a Mets fan for over 60 years, I have no problem with that.</p><p>But if Archbishop Hicks decides to replace the traditional recessional hymn after Mass with "Go Cubs Go," and if the Cubs meet <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/pope-leo-xiv" target="_blank" >Pope Leo XIV</a>'s White Sox in this year's World Series, I'll start going to Mass daily. </p><p>God bless New York AND Chicago. (God knows we both need it.)</p><p><i>Jim Vespe, Mamaroneck, New York</i> <br></p>
entries.author: Letters to the Editor

entries.title: Impressions Face and Body finds move to Old Town brings new energy to aesthetics practice
entries.summary: <div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d90000" name="module-d90000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b><i>Editor‚Äôs Note: </i></b><i>Last year, a new presidential administration stepped in with plans to disrupt the way companies do business through new policies, an effort to spur growth.</i><br><br><i>To help gauge the administration‚Äôs impact, the Chicago Sun-Times reached out to 10 Chicago area businesses in January 2025 and shared their plans and concerns for the future.</i><br><br><i>We‚Äôre now circling back, 12 months later, to see how they‚Äôve fared.</i></div> </div><p>After a year marked by growth ‚Äî from a relocation to a larger shift in the aesthetics industry ‚Äî Dr. Steven Dayan said his Chicago aesthetics clinic Impressions Face + Body now looks entirely different.</p><p>The practice moved last year from its long-time home in Streeterville to a newly-built center in Old Town ‚Äî a change Dayan describes as transformative. </p><p>‚ÄúThe move has completely changed the whole dynamic and face and delivery of who we are and what we have,‚Äù Dayan said. ‚ÄúIt finally matches the level of professionalism and expertise that we have. We have an office that equals it so it‚Äôs wonderful.‚Äù</p><p>The new center has three state-of-the-art procedure rooms and has a QUAD A accreditation, relatively few facilities in Chicago have an accreditation from QUAD A, formerly the American Association for Accreditation of Ambulatory Surgery Facilities.</p><p>The practice is also preparing to add a hyperbaric oxygen chamber in the next few weeks. While the treatment has grown in popularity for general wellness, Dayan said his team will use it primarily to support recovery. During the therapy, a patient breathes pure oxygen while inside a special pressurized chamber.</p><p>‚ÄúWe believe that it helps in the healing process,‚Äù he said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-b80000" name="image-b80000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5915792/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8e84832/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb56672/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="The main lobby of Impressions Face + Body at 224 W. Hill St. in the Old Town." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb56672/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6163544/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb56672/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+306/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F5e%2F91551bde4bcfba9a9bed38035dfa%2Fbizfinal-01xx26-16.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The main lobby of Impressions Face + Body at 224 W. Hill St. in the Old Town.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Few forces have shifted the aesthetic field more than GLP‚Äë1 drugs like Ozempic.</p><p>‚ÄúOzempic continues to be one of the greatest influences on our social culture, our society and aesthetic medicine in general,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe industry is expecting millions of people to come into the aesthetics funnel this year.‚Äù</p><p>His clinic, which he <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2025/03/07/weight-loss-drugs-ozempic-streeterville-impressions-plastic-surgery-clinic-facelifts" >founded in 2000</a>, now offers comprehensive GLP‚Äë1 support, including monitoring, hair loss prevention treatments, referrals to physical therapy for resistance training and nutrition counseling.</p><p>‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to get your GLP-1s here, and you‚Äôre going to be monitored closely aesthetically too, to make sure that, in parallel, you look good and feel good,‚Äù Dayan said.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-640000" name="module-640000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Impressions Face + Body</h3><b>About:</b> Plastic surgery clinic also offering non-surgical procedures<br><b>Neighborhood:</b> Loop<br><b>Owner:</b> Dr. Steven Dayan<br><b>Founded:</b> 2000<br><b>Staff size:</b> 27<br><b>Estimated annual revenue:</b> Undisclosed</div> </div><p>Economic uncertainty and industrywide trends have created an uneven landscape for aesthetic practices. Some national reports show declines for services like facial fillers, while surgery and biostimulators, or injections that help stimulate collagen production, have surged.</p><p>Dayan attributes some of the consumer pullback on injectables to experiencing inconsistent results across low-cost providers.</p><p>‚ÄúWe trained the masses ‚Ä¶ to do paint‚Äëby‚Äënumbers and recipe formulas,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat we got were results that really weren‚Äôt good.‚Äù</p><p>He said the clinic's Chicago clients prefer subtlety.</p><p>‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt want to show that they‚Äôve had anything done; they just want to look better," he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to see a Tiffany‚Äôs and Walmart divide when it comes to aesthetic experiences. And we‚Äôre going to cater to those people who want a more assured experience.‚Äù</p><p>The clinic's move to Old Town has brought a younger clientele, more foot traffic and a sense of renewed energy, Dayan said.</p><p>‚ÄúOld Town is a lot more current. It‚Äôs more relevant; it‚Äôs more dynamic,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like new energy. It‚Äôs exciting; it‚Äôs fun.‚Äù</p><p>The practice also started hosting open houses and happy hours for its neighbors in the surrounding buildings. ‚ÄúWe really want to be part of the community,‚Äù he said.</p><p>Despite economists anticipating broader economic challenges this year, Dayan said he remains optimistic. He‚Äôs also watching the rise of neurocosmetics, an emerging category of skincare designed to interact with the skin‚Äìbrain connection.</p><p>‚ÄúYour skin walks into the room before you do,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúLearning how to make that better first impression ‚Ä¶ I think that‚Äôs the next big thing.‚Äù</p><p>For now, he feels the practice is positioned for a strong year. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very optimistic about the coming year,‚Äù he said.</p><div class="PageListA" data-module ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-130001" name="list-130001"></a><div class="PageList-header" > <div entries.title: How we photographed the impact of Rev. Jesse Jackson's death
entries.summary: <p>This week‚Äôs top photo comes from visual journalist intern Giacomo Cain. Follow him on <a class="Link" href="https://www.instagram.com/gcain.photo" target="_blank" >Instagram</a>.</p><p></p><h3>What makes this photo important?</h3><p>U.S. Rep. Jonathan Jackson is one of six children to survive their father, civil rights leader the Rev. Jesse Jackson. All except one of Rev. Jackson‚Äôs children were present for a news conference Wednesday in front of the family's South Shore home. They spoke about their father‚Äôs legacy and his global impact. Rev. Jackson had been battling with progressive supranuclear palsy and died Tuesday. He was a groundbreaking icon who fought alongside Martin Luther King Jr. and founded Operation PUSH. His children told emotional stories of who he was as a father and a civil rights leader, describing him as dedicated to his pursuit of social justice. Jonathan Jackson is the second oldest of the siblings, and serves in Congress as a representative of the 1st District of Illinois.</p><h3>How did you get the photo?</h3><p>There are only so many different angles you can photograph people standing behind a mic, so once the press conference was finished, I documented interactions between Rev. Jackson's children, supporters, friends and family. With my telephoto lens, I stood on a mound of dirt to see above people‚Äôs heads. Given the emotional atmosphere, I was waiting for people to hug, which this photo shows. I try to capture emotion, because it shows real human nature and helps the viewer connect to the story. </p><p>While looking around for Rev. Jackson's children, Jonathan walked in my direction and approached a supporter. I raised my camera to my eye and snapped away. This is where my telephoto lens came in handy; I zoomed into Jonathan's face, excluding unnecessary elements and focusing on his expression. I really like his expression in this photo, because at first glance you see anguish, but if you look longer, you might see a hint of a smile. Whatever you see, for me, it makes me think of his love for his father and his passion for continuing his legacy.</p><h3>Technical details:</h3><ul class="rte2-style-ul"
